messages.content:
can you summarize this interview? Be sure to categorize and cluster information from this table into the interview so we can compare it with other interviews. Here is the interview:
- [[Interview-Metadata]] [[014 Interview]]
    - Direct_Blast_Experience:: False
[[Direct_Blast_Experience_False]]
    - Injury_From_Blast:: False
[[Injury_From_Blast_False]]
    - Code: Response-Migration Ideation:: False
    - Placebuilding_Ideation:: True
[[Placebuilding_Ideation_True]]
    - Know_Someone_Hurt:: True
[[Know_Someone_Hurt_True]]
    - Home_Damaged:: False
[[Home_Damaged_False]]
    - Office_Damaged:: False
[[Office_Damaged_Not Applicable]]
    - Prior_Migration_Experience:: True
[[Prior_Migration_Experience_True]]
    - Prior_Entrepreneurship_Program:: True
[[Prior_Entrepreneurship_Program]]
[[Code: Intuition]]
- [[History/Background]] [[014 Interview]]
    - Summary:
    - 
    - Weekend Plans?
        - [[Code: Family-Responsibility]] Cleaning and cooking. I have kids that need to eat. Tima is 13, Mia is 10. Job to do to work over the weekend. Training is happening so I need to fine tune over the weekend. Don't have any time to feel bored. [[Code: Response-Overworking]] I can't stop working, I keep thinking something is missing. I'm hyper active I always have to be doing something all the time. [[Code: Response-Overworking]] I'm also doing my masters, hoping to graduate in April. Global Smart City Management. This week is the last session of the last course. Thesis - coming up.
    - How many kids ?
        - 2 girls Teema 13 - mia is 10
    - Can you tell me about your history with entrepreneurship?
        - Masters - to graduate in April. Global Smart City Management. This week is the last session of the last course. Thesis - coming up.
        - [[Code: Risk]] [[Code: Important]] Started her job with dotLlebanon in 2013 - took a year to find a job. Directly I joined dot Lebanon - and been working/teaching at age 19. Teaching grade 9. Studying computer science at the same time she was teaching. Teaching I thought would be the last thing I'd do in my life. It was a school near my house, I got over at a part time. [[Code: Serendipity]] Bell rings, I can walk into the school (proximity) I have the skills [][Code: Skills]]. Doing a BS - got married directly after - met in University. Studying computer Engineering (husband) - got married. At that time I lived in Damascus, In Damascus I had a job in education. I was providing IGCSE - math, computer, etc. My husband started a business, and I thought maybe one day I'd like to start my own business. My dad is the opposite. He never likes these things. my mom has this mentality. My uncles are they all have their own businesses. My father in law is an entrepreneur. 
[[Code: Background-Entrepreneurial Family]]Husband doesn't like these things. in 2014 I saw this advertisement of Arab woman entrepreneurship program AMIDEAST - saw an advertisement. Untitled_10 In Syria worked in Education sector in one year and didn't find any job. She started a business. Buying and selling things online. When I found dot Lebanon job - mix of speciality as a computer scientist and experience in education. Integrating technology - student centered classrooms with USAID program. DOTLebanon everything was developed in house so I was learning lots of things and putting in lots of effort [[Code: Empowerment-Through-Learning]]. Programs/Curriculum. Lots of effort. At the same time I had to do something that empowers educators. [[Code: Volunteering]] I want to do a training for teachers provide them 21st century skills for the classroom. Academy for 9 months with AMIDEast [[Code: Experience-Prior-Entrepreneurial-Training]]- exchange programs with US embassy. TechWoman program in 2016. I don't know what will happen I have to start my own business. Nothing is stable. So I thought I should start my own business to be more stable. Lost my dad in 2014 and realized it's not time to start.  [[Code: Thinking about death]] [[Code: Reappraisal]] If you're working with an NGO - if they didn't get a new fund it was risky. I have to start my own business to guarantee things especially with the whole situation we find ourselves in. Went to a bank, planned everything her / husband - ready to start 2015 - 2016 - filling application for techwoman. Go visit top tech/it/steam companies in San Francico - 2016 i went for 1.5 months. Visited Google, Instagram. It was an amazing program. Went to DC and it was very fruitful. Was hosted by SCI-ARC - preserve archeological sites around the world through 3d scanning. If things are destroyed they can fix it again. I was responsible for the educational part. (Biggest takeaway from that trip?) there are many many things that I have gained? The atmosphere that you find. The work atmosphere was really amazing.  [[Code: Fun-at-work]]. [[Code: Positive-Peer-Inspiration]] Everyone would come at anytime, sit comfortably. Each one feels responsible, they have their space for creativity. People love what they're doing. [[Code: Social-Awareness]] Very open, they share everything they have. It's an atmosphere we're not used to it in the Middle East.  Over there it was amazing. Keep updated and share the knowledge they have. [[Code: Positive-Peer-Inspiration]]Everything with my job and with my team and everything in my life there are a lot of lessons you can bring it in. Started to know more about stem/steam doing more of my research. In the states in learning more about entrepreneurship/leadership. Technovasion (she's now the ambassador for girls and the business part). Technovasion (she's now the ambassador for girls and the business part). To encourage them to start business. We apply for a fund, it's a free program. Mentors. It's an NGO over there. Travelled for the last few years for many different training. Turning point for me, through travel to the states and Italy. You can mention one word in front of me and we go and do research to stay on top of things. If things are not being used any more we keep updated. [[Code: Empowerment-Through-Learning]]
    - Can you tell me about your decision making process when you decided to start your own business?
        - It's my nature to have a lot of projects going on. [[Code: Response-Overworking]]
If I stop thinking I feel like something is missing. Problem with the dollar rate, everything is so expensive. Raised the rent 2 times now. I'm paying more than I am receiving. Income is not enough from students attending. We only increased our prices by 1 dollar - to cover the expenses of detergents / alcohol / masks. [[Code: Feeling-Compassion]] Didn't want to look like we're abusing things so we moved entirely online.
increased rent and electricity. [[Code: Financial]] Six to 10x as much for the parents is hard to do. Only online - 
This week was pretty hard because I had to inform the parents we're not open. [[Code: Feeling-Sad]] We won't open again for now. Since we won't be able to increase prices. Wake up 12000 15000 10000 every day it's different. In the afternoon it's different from the morning. This was not an easy decision. It's not only happening with me, it's happening with everyone. To shift online. Start digitizing other courses. [[Code: Strategic]] [[Code: Feeling-Stuck]] We need a miracle I say.
    - How do you feel now after making that decision?
        - We were trying to postpone it for over a year now. It's either we close down, or shift online. and slowly change things and see where we are heading. [[Code: Adaptation]] Milk or other things. I plan things ahead. I buy everything once a month. It's month by month I have a full basket and I know what I need. That's how I plan things. [[Code: Strategic]] Everyday you get the things you use day to day. other than that it's like everyone. It's not in my agenda to leave the country. [[Code: Response-Anti-Migration Ideation]]You can easily find a job abroad. I don't like to leave my country. Many people tell me you have these skills and experience. You can easily find a job. I don't like to leave. I don't want to leave for many reasons, my husband is not Lebanese he's Syrian - I came in 2012 in the beginning of the revolution and he came in 2013/2014 - we came here about 6 years fighting to start edutech [[Code: Response-Anti-Migration Ideation]] [[Code: Visa-Issues]]. He's a computer engineer. For Syrians it's not easy - the girls won a competition to go to the states. They're not accepted because of their nationality. Don't want to leave this stress again. [[Code: Feeling-Fear]]
We're lucky, my husband is married to a Lebanese person and he can get his Iqama (residency) here and so we're lucky. Look on the positive side of things [[Code: Value-Optimism]] [[Code: Feeling-Gratitude]]
- [[Ethnographic Questions]] [[014 Interview]]
    - Gender:: Female
    - Age:: 38
    - Origin:: I'm Lebanese my husband is Syrian. Good enough to have an Iqama here and we're lucky. He has a consultant - and I work at the NGO .Lebanon getting fresh dollars. Some stability with fresh dollars. Maybe this is the thing that is stable. [[Code: Response-Seek-Stability]] Mom is here. His parents are in Syria and my parents are closer. 
Been in the states and other countries. [[Code: Travel]] It's not easy. They are more difficult than here(In America). [[Code: Response-Anti-Migration Ideation]]
    - Residence:: Bekaa
    - Family_Income_Bracket:: Lower Middle
    - Family: Married at 24, has two kids now 
- [[Entrepreneurial Intent Questions]] [[014 Interview]]
    - EI_Score:: 34
    - EI_Employment_Status:: Self employed
    - EI3: Estimate the probability (0-100%) you will start your own business in the next 5 years?
        - I already have my own business. I had good opportunities/connections with people (concern about abuse without being registered). [[Code: Risk-Mitigation]] [[Code: Risk]] [[Code: Strategic]] Launched a sister company in Amman - hopefully after covid we'll work on it. Before edutech I had the opportunity to work in Jordan, I didn't want. Covid and the economic challenges postponed that plan. [[Code: Personality-Entrepreneurial]]
    - I’m ready to make anything to be an entrepreneur
        - I can't leave my job for example. At least not for now.
    - My professional goal is becoming an entrepreneur
        - It's not becoming an entrepreneur. It's more about through entrepreneurship achieving my aspirations in life. [[Code: Entrepreneurial-Ideation]] What I can do in entrepreneurship I can do what I //really// want to do. I want to focus on digital transformation. It's what I'm learning in my masters. Upgrading our business. 
    - What does it mean to "know what you really want to do"
        -  Believing, we discuss everything together with my husband. We depend on each other. [[Code: Family]] [[Code: Social-Support]] Someone is more technical - the other is more communication networking/planning. He's better at technical things, we decide what we want to do and it's a feeling inside that makes you feel like this is what I want. It's like "Tada" - click this is what I want.
- [[Impact of Event Scale IES-R]] [[014 Interview]]
    - IES-R_Intrusion:: 21
    - IES-R_Avoidance:: 14
    - IES-R_Hyper_Arousal:: 19
    - IES-R_Interpretation:: 37+: This is high enough to suppress your immune system's functioning (even 10 years after an impact event)
    - IES-R_Score:: 54
    - What are some of the changes in your life since the August 4th blast?
        - I was not affected, since I was not living directly in Beirut. First reaction was to start crying. We are living this again and again. It's not safe. [[Code: Feeling-Fear]]. We left Damascus because it's not safe for our kids and we're living it again. 30 years of civil war. Will this ever end? It's not safe, it's not secure. [[Code: Feeling-Anxious]] [[Code: Feeling-Fear]]
    - How did the blast affect your thinking/thinking about your projects?
        - Actually my thinking is everyone is thinking about leaving. Something inside me that doesn't want to leave despite everything. I don't know why I'm still calm. I see the craziness all around us. The best thing you can do is focus with what you have [[Code: Self-Determination]] [[Code: Value-Agency]] [[Code: Needing-Control]] [[Code: Altruism]], and how you can help others with what you have. if you focus on all the bad things around us you can't work. What I decided is to help and doing what I can do and keeping my mental health and family health and that's how to survive thing. Of course we felt very bad and it was very stressful for us and all these feelings. I just wanted to stay calm. 
    - How are you maintaining your mental health?
        - I was listening all the time to the quran. For seven months - this is the only thing that really helped me. It really calmed me down. Keeping it at home. Although I am really the last person on earth that would do that. It was a turning point in my life. Because I was not really religous. I was always postponing to do this later. I was always maqassarah, I needed to have this peace and every day I wanted to listen / know more. Since 7 months. Since when I'm doing dishes I am listening. 
Quran is like Magic. [[Code: Religious-Prioritization]] [[Code: Spirituality-Reliance on God]] [[Code: Spirituality]]
Baqarah, kahf mostly. Abdul Kafi = 3mr khalid. Listen to them. Look at things differently. 	Youtube. all the time, I follow the channels on youtube. I put it on my phone haram - my kids have to bear this all time. I close the door. I listen when I'm doing my chores. When I feel inspired I put up the ayahs on my Facebook. I'm muslim on brith, and I never knew what things mean till I really started listening. Quran? Ayah - I just need some time to think about it. I usually share them on my facebook. Sometimes. I'm Muslim in Birth - And many things I didn't know till I started listening to them deeply. When you have this call from your heart. You start really understanding and knowing the difference. Praying for praying. It's really changed.
        - One of the things, you have lots of trials. Now I understand these trials are blessings. They will be a shafa3a (purification) for you. It's how you look at things and they will change your perspective. I understood why. You feel you wannt tell the whole I want my kids to have it from a very young age. Anse - mu3alimah deen. She lives in kuwait. Not in the daish way, more like it's supposed to be. I'm happy they are having a session every week. Don't want them to be like me so old to know the religion [[Code: Religious-Prioritization]]
    - Any reminder brought back feelings about it
        - Insecurity, lack of accountability. Very tough. Yes and I control it. [[Code: Feeling-Injustice]] [[Code: Security]]
    - I had trouble staying asleep
        - I don't sleep much anyway. I have trouble staying asleep.I don't know if it's from it, I am always worried/thinking about many things. It's a part of it. It's in the back of our brains [[Code: Feeling-Anxious]]
    - I felt irritable and angry
        - Injustice. Injustice for everyone, people who died. The moms/dads who lost kids/parents. Everything people in this country - very sad [[Code: Feeling-Injustice]] [[Code: Feeling-Sad]]
    - I felt as if it hadn't happened or wasn't real
        - Yes, how could this happen? This couldn't happen - I think people believe that it's a nightmare.
    - I stayed away from reminders about it
        - I don't stay away - I face things [[Code: Value-Self knowledge]] [[Code: Value-Self knowledge]]
    - I was aware that I still had a lot of feelings about it, but I didn't deal with them
        - because I deal with my feelings [[Code: Value-Self knowledge]]
    - Did you know people affected by the blast directly?
        - One of the things, you have lots of trials. Now I understand these trials are blessings. They will be a shafa3a for you. It's how you look at things and they will change your perspective. [[Code: Silver-Linings]][[Code: Value-Hope]] I understood why. You feel you wanna tell the whole story. I want my kids to have it from a very young age. Anse - mu3alimah deen. She lives in Kuwait. Not in the Daish way, more like it's supposed to be. I'm happy they are having a session every week. Don't want them to be like me so old to know the religion. [[Code: Spirituality]]
    - What are your first memories of what happened then?
    - How did you hear about the news
        - Opening the TV. Directly at the time I was looking at the TV I was looking out the window and it was an orange sky - it was at the same moment.
    - Where were you when the blast happened
        - I was at home in the Bekaaa
- [[Resilience BRCS]] [[014 Interview]]
    - BRCS_Score:: 20
    - BRCS_Interpretation:: High resilient coping: 17-20
    - How have you been coping after the blast?
        - What she was doing was more focusing on shifting the work to do the things to help people. [[Code: Volunteering]] [[Code: Altruism]] We focus on how to help people. We were affected psychologically, some people affected directly physically, I had many friends who lost their houses, colleagues, brothers / sisters affected. The first thing was to help, change everything to prioritize this. We helped in sending food, collecting digital forms to support people. Sharing resources. helping in cleaning up. Supporting people. [[Code: Volunteering]] 
    - - Regardless of what happens to me, I believe I can control my reaction to it.
        -  [[Code: Self-Control]]before no, now I do. I'm surprised I do. I'm trying to become a less emotional person. It caused me lots of problems. I take my time to think about my reactions before I do them? [[Code: Adaptation]]
    - How did you develop this ability?
        - After losing everything and one year without a job, and having a family and risking a new place. And I had to take a new job which deals with training and people and teachers. If I did not manage my emotions It could be risking my job. I started controlling my emotions/reactions.  [[Code: Self-Control]]I was also abused a lot for my reactions. [[Code: Emotion-stability]]I don't express my emotions unless it's not extreme. It's a balanced emotion. Even my political views. I was an activist before I didn't express anything.
[[Code: Needing-Control]] [[Code: Security]] It's not easy. It's something you have to work on very much, it started from there. Started to control her reactions. Everything revolves around security at that time
- [[Post Traumatic Growth Index]] [[014 Interview]]
    - PTGI_Score:: 87
    - PTGI_Average:: 4.142857143
    - PTGI_Appreciation of life:: 15
    - PTGI_Spiritual Enhancement:: 10
    - PTGI_Relating to others:: 25
    - PTGI_New Possibilities:: 18
    - PTGI_Personal Strength:: 19
    - I changed my priorities about what is important in life.
        - It's not only the blast. I've experienced this a lot, in Lebanon, in Syria... When you have this in your life. I experienced this a lot, it's been a tough 10 years for me. I've witnessed many bombs in Syria. We lost my husband's brother (We don't know where he is) [[Code: Experience-Prior-Violence]] I lost my dad in a 7 month battle with cancer. [[Code: Loss]] The blast wasn't the only thing that caused this change. Blast/economical situation, everything. [[Code: Family]] [[Code: Reprioritization]]
    - I developed new interests.
        - Developed an interest in auctions. Nothing to be amused with so I spend money on auctions. People are adapting 100 auctions on whatsapp. I just buy things on them. Lebanese people are always good at adapting. Always a new way to cope with things. Closing their shops, now shifted to buying/selling with technology. Everyone is shifting and learning and adapting [[Code: Adaptation]]
    - I more clearly see that I can count on people in times of trouble.
        - Not everyone, certain people were there when I needed them [[Code: Response-Self Protection]]
    - I established a new path for my life.
        - Not a new path
    - I am more willing to express my emotions.
        - Not everyone, not all the time. Depends on emotions expressing boldly not making things look nicer [[Code: Value-Privacy]]
    - I am able to do better things with my life.
        - hopefully [[Code: Feeling-Hopeful]] 
    - I put more effort into my relationships.
        - The ones that deserve it. The ones that don't deserve I'm putting 0 efforts. [[Code: Reprioritization]] [[Code: Relationships]] Sometimes you put the right effort even if they don't deserve it and it's your duty to do it. [[Code: Response-Judgement]] [[Code: Family-Responsibility]] doing it because it's a wajib, because your conscious tells you to do it not because they deserve it. 
    - I discovered that I'm stronger than I thought I was.
        - I don't know... I used to do everything. I don't want to drop anything from my hand. I'm learning to drop/postpone things because I can't carry it on. It's a strength for me. I didn't put the right focus/effort on edutech. I'm ok with it, khalas. Things will happen at the right time. I don't want to overburden myself otherwise I'll collapse. [[Code: Value-Self knowledge]] [[Code: Value-Independence]] Maybe later I'll discover I was wrong. If I go back I might make the same decision
    - I learned a great deal about how wonderful people are.
        - There are really wonderful people  
    - I better accept needing others.
        - Before I wouldn't want any help from others, [[Code: Value-Independence]] [[Code: Social-Support]] now I allow others to help me. Not a lot and not everyone. Part of my character is to not ask for help, difficult to open for anyone, admitting. [[Code: Feeling-Unwilling-to-trust]]
- [[Rumination]] [[014 Interview]]
    - Intrusive_Rumination_Score:: 26
    - Deliberate_Rumination_Score:: 34
    - Deliberate_Rumination_Ratio:: 57%
    - Deliberate_Rumination_Interpretation:: Mid 50-75
- [[Concluding Statements]] [[014 Interview]]
    - Can you tell me a little about what has been supporting you personally and professionally since the blast?
        - Got some opportunities in different trainings. ACSI, all the mentorship/exposure network. Hearing experiences from different people. Everyone has something to add for you. If someone shares something I will think about it, researcher mindset, I will reflect on it to see if I can use it. The SheInstitute, a Swedish program for women it was very insightful. All the things she's learned. Attending all the different training online. A Masters program, new course, new skills, new ideas. Meeting people online. As well as we had to adapt to being online and having to shift everything online. New ways and shifting new ways adding new skills and professional skills. [[Code: Competence]] [[Code: Empowerment-Through-Learning]] Doing things online needs specific types of things. Personal growth - sticking more to my faith/religion. Helped a lot [[Code: Spirituality]] [[Code: Religious-Prioritization]]
    - What role do you see entrepreneurs having in a place like Lebanon given the current situation?
        - Rebuilding Lebanon. [[Code: Feeling-Hopeful]]
    - Do you believe entrepreneurs can rebuild Lebanon?
        - Yes. I believe we will always find a way. [[Code: Value-Hope]] It's not something new in Lebanon. People don't stop. Many have traveled and left Lebanon. Every situation furas and ma2asee have furas. People here are creative. If you look at the Syrians and what they're doing in the different countries of the world wherever they are, they are creative. In spite of the 70 million things in us we have creativity. And we try to adapt . Trying to go online, finding new ways/opportunities. It's the time for entrepreneurs. If we don't have entrepreneurs, new ideas, creativity, will help find solutions to the problems we find in the country right now. Because the government in Lebanon doesn't have or do anything. Solutions and garbage. Entrepreneurs do/think about it. [[Code: Entrepreneurship-Solution to problems]] [[Code: Feeling-Patriotism]][[Code: Feeling-Pride]] [[Code: Value-Optimism]] [[Code: Value-Creativity]]
- [[roam/comments]]
    - [[June 2nd, 2021]]
        - Can you tell me about your history with entrepreneurship?

Here are the scores for this interview:Name	Education Level	Living_With_Family	Have_Children	Gender	Age	Age_Range	Income Bracket	Income Simplified	Region	Origin	Region Class	EI_Employment_Status	Employment Simplified	EI - Entrepreneurial Intentions	EI - Interpretation	EI Norm	IES-R Total	IES-R Interpretation	IESR Norm	Hyperarousal IES-R	Avoidance IES-R copy	Intrusion IES-R	BRCS	BRCS Norm	BRCS_Interpretation	PTGI Total	PTGI Norm	PTGI Average Score	PTGI - Interpretation	PTGI - Appreciation	PTGI - Spiritual Enhancement	PTGI - Relating to others	PTGI - New possibilities	PTGI - Personal Strength	EERI Intrusive - Event Related Rumination Inventory	EERI Deliberate - Event Related Rumination Inventory Deliberate	Deliberate_Rumination_Ratio	Deliberate_Rumination_Interpretation	Attachments	Status	Pre-Post Interpretation	Avg Character Strengths Difference Post-Pre	Character Strength Average Score	Character Strengths Norm	Character Strengths Difference Individual Strength and Strength Average	Direct_Blast_Experience	Injury_From_Blast	Migration_Ideation	Placebuilding_Ideation	Know_Someone_Hurt	Home_Damaged	Office_Damaged copy	Has_Therepist	Entrepreneurial_Family	International_Travel	Prior Migration Experience	Prior_Entrepreneurship_Program	In_Bloom_Program	Contrarian-Thinking	Experience-Prior-Violence	Revolutionary_Ideation	Meditator	Top 5 Strengths	Top 3 Strengths	Signature Strength	Hope Average	Hope Segmentation	Humor Average	Humor Segmentation	Spirituality Average	Spirituality Segmentation	Gratitude Average	Gratitude Segmentation	Kindness Average	Kindness Segmentation
14	Masters		TRUE	Female	38	35-44	Lower Middle	Lower	Bekaa	Damascus - Syria	Rural	Self employed	Self Employed	34	3 High	0.94	54	37+ High	0.61	19	14	21	20	1	17-20 High	87	0.83	4.14	4-6 High	15	10	25	18	19	26	34	0.57	50-65 Mid			3 Increase	2.02	24	1	2.74	FALSE	FALSE	FALSE	TRUE	TRUE	FALSE	FALSE	Unsure	TRUE	TRUE	TRUE	TRUE	TRUE	FALSE	TRUE	Unsure		Authenticity,Creativity,Kindness,Prudence,Bravery	Authenticity,Creativity,Kindness	Authenticity	23	High	23	High	20	High	21.67	High	23	High

The interview with a 38-year-old female from Bekaa, Lebanon, who has a Masters degree and is self-employed, provides a comprehensive overview of her experiences, challenges, and thoughts about entrepreneurship and life in general in Lebanon. Below is a summary categorized and clustered as per the themes observed in the interview:

### Personal and Family Background
- The interviewee is married with two children, aged 13 and 10. She is busy with family responsibilities, her job, and is currently completing her masters in Global Smart City Management.
- She has a significant family influence in entrepreneurship, mentioning that her uncles and father-in-law run their own businesses, although her father and husband are less inclined towards entrepreneurship.

### Professional Journey
- Her professional journey began with a teaching job at 19 while studying computer science. She has worked in various educational roles, emphasizing technology integration in the classroom.
- She participated in entrepreneurship programs and exchange programs, including the TechWoman program in the USA, which greatly influenced her views on workplace atmosphere and creativity.

### Business and Entrepreneurial Activities
- She started her own business in education, which she later had to shift entirely online due to economic challenges, including issues with rent and utility costs.
- Despite challenges, she is proactive about adapting her business to the changing economic landscape, and she expresses a strong desire to stay in Lebanon and contribute to its rebuilding through entrepreneurship.

### Mental and Emotional Health
- The interviewee discusses the impact of the August 4th Beirut blast and previous experiences in Syria on her mental health. She turned to spirituality and listening to the Quran for solace.
- She scored high on resilience and post-traumatic growth, indicating strong coping mechanisms and a capacity to find personal strength in adversity.

### Impact of Events and Coping Strategies
- She has a high score on the Impact of Event Scale, showing significant psychological impact from the Beirut blast, but she did not experience it directly.
- Her coping strategies are focused on helping others and adapting to circumstances, underlining her community-focused and resilient nature.

### Reflections on Entrepreneurship in Lebanon
- She believes strongly in the role of entrepreneurs in rebuilding Lebanon, emphasizing the creativity and adaptability of the Lebanese people.
- Despite challenges, she remains hopeful and committed to her entrepreneurial ventures and sees opportunities for growth and stability in the region.

### Comparative Analysis with Other Interviews
- Compared to others, she exhibits a high level of entrepreneurial intent and resilience, making her a strong example of leadership in adversity.
- Her scores on the Post Traumatic Growth Index and the Resilience Scale are relatively high, reflecting her ability to derive strength from challenging experiences.

This detailed summary allows for a comparison with other interviews to identify unique or common themes across different respondents' experiences and perceptions.
